Home / Case Studies / Cadence Fitness

Workout logging that tracks the full picture.

  • Self-initiated
  • 2026

A strength training app that captures the context behind each set — equipment, variations, rest, and training methods — without slowing down logging.

This project allowed me to develop my use of AI-augmented prototyping and development as I worked to solve a real personal pain point.

Role

  • Research
  • Design
  • Content
  • Development
  • Testing
    (moderated + unmoderated)

Problem

“Why does this feel harder than last time?”

Regular gym-goers often want to track progress consistently, but variations in machine callibration, setup, and personal settings — even on the same exercise — make like-for-like comparison unreliable. Without context, numbers alone don’t tell the full story.

Additionally, many existing gym trackers add friction rather than clarity. Basic logging is often buried inside bloated feature sets, making it harder to understand real progress.

Validation

  • Input from personal trainers and regular gym users.
  • A short survey shared within fitness-focused social communities.

Project goals

  • Flexible & efficient logging
  • Like-for-like, contextual comparison
  • In-the-moment progress indicators
  • Focused - no fluff
  • Offline first
  • Cost effective
  • Immediate value

Equipment calibration and settings can significantly impact exercise work rate across sessions.
Image: ChatGPT

Core flows mapped in Miro.

Process

I followed a deliberately lightweight, iterative process focused on learning through use rather than documentation.

High-level flows were first mapped in Miro to validate the core logging and review journeys. These flows were then translated into Figma, where interaction details were prototyped, refined, and simplified through repeated passes.

An offline-first architecture means all data lives on the device. This allowed me to quickly build an installable proof of concept and test it in real gym sessions — both personally and with a small group of friends. Observation and feedback from real workouts directly informed each iteration, keeping the work grounded in practical, in-the-moment use rather than theoretical scenarios.

Concept development

Early concepts were roughed out on paper.
I designed a tagging system to capture the nuance of any given exercise…

…and developed the idea as part of the inital wireframes in Figma.

Early-flow interactive prototypes.

Storing data on the device and using AI-augmented development allowed me to rapidly iterate and test in real conditions with real users.

Screens from the beta release - in Google Play Store closed testing (as of February 2026)

Reflection & next steps

Building on established prototyping practice, this project explored how tools such as ChatGPT Codex can meaningfully accelerate the path from idea to working product.

Interaction design and flow definition were familiar territory, but the work reinforced how early design decisions directly shape code structure, data integrity, and long-term flexibility.

The key learning was the value of treating prototypes as structural artefacts, not just interaction proofs. In future work, I would involve technical constraints earlier and use prototyping to actively de-risk architecture as well as UX.

From a training perspective, I have found seeing the accurate context - exactly what I did last time - has been a spur to work a little harder.

With a wider release, the focus shifts to learning from real usage and evolving the product through measured iteration rather than feature expansion.

Based in London.

Designing product experiences that feel inevitable.
